I think the distinction will fall at customization as expression. If a product or service is standardized for anyone who buys it, such as a box of cookies, a hotel room, a meal at a restaurant, or a bike rental, then you can't discriminate, because there is no distinction in your expressive input. However, where the product or service requires your particular skills to produce something unique and customized, as a wedding cake typically is, or demands that you provide something you normally wouldn't, then the First Amendment is implicated, and you cannot be forced to do so. I think this outcome is the only one that emerges while leaving the precedent in Hobby Lobby (protecting a business owner's religious expression as it effects business decisions) and the family of anti-discrimination cases like Heart of Atlanta Hotel and Katzenbach v. McClung fully intact (since they all involve products or services that are the same regardless of who is ordering it. I.e., there is no expression involved with providing the product or service).

In reading CADA and SOEDA (https://www.colorado.gov/pacific/costillacounty/atom/3111) and the federal Civil Rights act, I see nothing about anti-discrimination on goods a company sells or refuses to sell. Saying Yes to this case would establish extreme pressures on American business. For example, if a person who doesn't believe in blood transfusions were forced to take blood, could the hospital be sued?  If a business advertised that they made special cakes for those with Autism, would those without Autism sue? Unless I'm not reading the laws correctly, I see no statute related to a company refusing to give a particular service or not to a customer walking in the store. Currently, federal anti-discrimination laws say businesses can refuse service to any person for any reason, unless the business is discriminating against a protected class. At the national (and Colorado state level) level protected classes are only based on race or color. SOEDA does put sexual orientation into a protected class but not for refusal of service, only for specific employment matters. The baker couldn't refuse hiring a same-sex married couple for the same-sex reason only.

It seems to me that the whole "public accommodation" thing is a red herring. I would imagine (although I may be wrong) that a willingness to sell cakes to customers as they walk into the shop meets the public accommodation burden. The baker said he was willing to sell cakes to the original plaintiffs, but was unwilling to create a bespoke cake for their wedding. So here's a question: what if the baker had said that he wouldn't bake the cake, and gave no reason; he simply turned down the job. Would the plaintiffs have had grounds to sue? How about if the baker had said, "Thanks, but I'd rather take that day off." Would the plaintiffs had grounds to sue then?  In other words, can the baker legally turn down the assignment for a non-religious reason or even without stating any reason at all? Is it only a crime if the baker turns down the assignment if he or she gives a religious reason for doing so? Because in that case, it probably can be framed as religious freedom issue.
